summary: This document is a chain of emails from September-October 2019 between prosecutors and agents discussing the taint review process for electronic materials seized from Jeffrey Epstein's Manhattan residence. The emails express concern that the volume of documents (20,000) seems low given the number of devices seized (approximately 38 computers/storage devices and 55 CDs) and seek clarification on data locations and review status.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The seized materials are from his Manhattan residence, and his attorney provided search terms for the taint review.

persons.name: Eland
persons.role: Individual consulted about data on a drive
persons.context: An email mentions checking with Eland, who reported there was not very much on a drive related to the seized materials.

connections.description: Eland is consulted about the contents of a drive from seized materials related to Epstein's residence, suggesting a professional or technical connection to the case data.

events.title: Seized materials made available
events.description: Materials seized from Jeffrey Epstein's Manhattan residence were made available for review.

events.title: Supervisors request taint review update
events.description: Supervisors requested a status update on the taint review process before a meeting with the ADIC about the case.

events.title: Taint review search terms run
events.description: An attorney reported running all search terms provided by Epstein's attorney and segregating the hits, noting there were not many.

locations: New York, NY 10007 (Southern District of New York office)
keyFacts: Approximately 38 computers and/or electronic storage devices and an additional 55 CDs were seized from Epstein's Manhattan residence.
The taint review initially yielded about 20,000 documents, but prosecutors expressed skepticism that this volume was low given the number of devices seized.
Epstein's attorney provided search terms for the taint review of seized materials.
The emails show internal coordination and concern within the prosecution team about the completeness of data processing from the seizures.
